page.title: 18LISTED BUILDINGS
page.content: Some of the farmhouses are Listed Grade II buildings of historic interest. Most farmhouses were built in timber_framing in oak which was plentiful in the area. Wall panels were filled with wattle and daub, later covered with timber weather_ boarding or tile_hanging when these became readily available. Roofs were normally thatched originally but this later gave way to clay tiles which had the advantage of being fireproof. Windows were originally unglazed, later with wood sliding or hinged casements, and later still with wood sliding sashes and iron casement. Several old houses have interesting 'Dry_ways' running down to the old sea_shore. They have high banks and are partly sunken, giving great privacy. They were probably used by smugglers in days gone by.
